title: Open Science Framework
text:
About the OSF
The Open Science Framework (OSF) is a free, open-source platform that supports researchers across disciplines in managing, sharing, and storing research projects throughout the entire research lifecycle. OSF allows users to preregister studies, share data and materials, collaborate with team members, and make research products openly accessible. It helps enhance transparency, reproducibility, and collaboration in science.
Researchers, clinicians, and students can use OSF to organize projects, publish preprints, and connect with open science initiatives worldwide.

title: Julia Stanfield, BS
text:
Biography
Julia Stanfield’s research interests include pediatric motor speech disorders, adolescent and adult alternative augmentative communication (AAC) use, and acquired neurogenic communication disorders. She is especially interested in how sexual education is integrated into AAC use and the benefits of integrating sexual education into AAC use.
Julia received her Bachelors of Science in Speech Language Hearing Sciences at the University of Cincinnati, with a Deaf Studies certificate in May 2025. In her undergraduate experience, she partnered with Cincinnati Children’s Hospital Medical Center SLPs, identifying the efficacy of current treatment for exercise-induced laryngeal obstruction (EILO) patients, which was presented at the ASHA Convention in 2024. Currently, she is pursuing her masters degree in the Communication Sciences program at CWRU and is a graduate research assistant and thesis student in the CaSE lab.
Throughout her masters studies, she is completing clinical practica across pediatric and adult settings. Outside of academics, Julia enjoys reading, baking, cycling, seeing live theatre, and doing nail art.

Biography
Jada is an undergraduate studying Psychology and Communication Sciences, with a minor in Public Health. She is interested in many aspects of human behavior and conditions. Jada enjoys learning from idiographic studies to see what causes individual differences. She also enjoys nomothetic studies to look at group behaviors and what causes them. Those interests are what guided her to make those specific major and minor selections. Post graduation, she hopes to have a career that involves research and working with individual patients. Outside of academics, Jada enjoys watching horror movies and completing unique art projects.

title: World CP Day 2025
text:
This week, the CaSE Lab team celebrated World Cerebral Palsy Day as a global event dedicated to raising awareness, building understanding, and celebrating the lives and contributions of people with cerebral palsy.
We marked the day by wearing our custom CP awareness t-shirts and enjoying an array of green snacks as the color representing CP awareness. But the heart of our celebration was a meaningful discussion centered on the voices and stories of people with CP.
We watched and reflected on three powerful videos by Special Books by Special Kids (SBSK) on YouTube, each featuring a different person living with CP: Maya, Avery, and Sonel. Through their stories, we explored the diversity of CP experiences, noting the similarities and differences in how CP affects people’s lives. Most importantly, we focused on who each person is beyond their diagnosis: their personalities, interests, likes and dislikes, and the ways they navigate the world.
This discussion helped us deepen our understanding of CP as more than a medical condition–it’s a part of a person’s story, but never the whole story. Students shared takeaways about individuality, communication, and the importance of listening to lived experiences as we continue our work to support people with CP and their families.

title: The CaSE Lab is now on Instagram!
text: The Communication and Speech Emergence (CaSE) Lab is excited to share that we’re now on Instagram! You can find us at @caselab_cwru. This is a space where we’ll share the people, projects, and purpose driving our work to support early communication development in children with cerebral palsy and other neurodevelopmental disabilities. We also plan to highlight work from related labs, and educational content for SLPs and families all about supporting early communication development in young children with or at high risk for CP.

title: The CaSE Lab is now on Instagram!
text:
What to Expect:
Our Instagram will be a behind-the-scenes look at life in the lab and the impact of our work. You’ll see:

Research in Action: Highlights from our ongoing studies on early vocal and communication development and AAC interventions.
Community Partnerships: Collaborations with families, clinicians, and organizations that help translate research into real-world support for SLPs and families.
Student & Team Spotlights: Meet the researchers, clinicians, and students who make the work possible.
Educational Insights: Tips, infographics, and takeaways about communication development, early identification, and evidence-based intervention practices.
Events & Outreach: Updates on research presentations, community events, caregiver programs, CP news, and more.

Our mission is to advance early identification, intervention, and support for communication needs in children with motor disabilities, and to do so in partnership with families and communities. Our Instagram will be another way to connect, share, and learn together.
We hope you’ll join us on this journey to build a more communication-centered future. 💚

title: Ava Ng ASHA 2025 Meritorious Poster
text:
Congratulations to lab member Ava Ng for having her presentation accepted to the 2025 ASHA Convention and for receiving a Meritorious Poster Award!
Ava will be presenting work she completed with her IMPACT mentor at Boys Town National Research Hospital, Dr. Kaylah Lalonde, on the “Influence of audiovisual speech cues on listening effort in school-age children”.
During Ava’s tenure in the IMPACT Program at CWRU she leaned into gaining research experience and taking full advantage of having a research mentor from Boys Town. Because of her dedication and excellence in this area, she was invited to spend a summer at Boys Town where she completed much of this work.
Congratulations, Ava! We are so proud of you!

title: AACPDM 2025 Conference
text:
The CaSE Lab had four co-authored abstract submissions accepted to present at the 2025 AACPDM Annual meeting this October!

Sutter, E, Iverson, J, & Long HL (Submitted for 2025, October). Bridging the Gap: Exploring Motor-Communication Links and Clinical Implications through a Developmental Cascades Framework [Educational Session].

This session explores how motor and communication development are interconnected across neurodevelopmental disabilities. Using a developmental cascades framework, presenters will review research on motor-communication links and discuss clinical strategies to support communication outcomes for children with motor delays or impairments. 

Long HL, Anderson, D, & Michalski, K (Submitted for 2025, October). Tiny Voices Matter. The Impact of Early Communication: Insights from Research and Clinic [Educational Session].

This session discusses the role of SLPs in promoting early communication and participation for children with cerebral palsy. Topics include key milestones, referral considerations, and intervention strategies, such as parent coaching and AAC, to support language development and challenge common misconceptions about early speech and AAC use in CP. 

Hidecker, MJC, Long HL, & Lenski, M (Submitted for 2025, October). Descriptive epidemiology of functional communication among children aged 10 born extremely prematurely [Free Paper].

This poster presents a descriptive epidemiology of communication functioning at age 10 among children born extremely preterm. Using a range of speech, language, and communication measures, findings show that up to 28% had reduced communication abilities, highlighting the significant long-term communication needs in this population compared to national averages. 

Long HL, Romer K, Rivera-Peraza, C, Spence D, Chen, S, & Rhodes L (Submitted for 2025, October). Referral and Clinical Practices for Speech Therapy in a Multidisciplinary CP Clinic [Poster].

This poster describes referral patterns and clinical practices for SLP services in a multidisciplinary clinic for children with cerebral palsy. Findings show earlier referrals for feeding concerns and later referrals for communication delays, emphasizing the need for timely identification and intervention to optimize communication outcomes.

title: CTSC Annual Pilot Award
text:
CaSE Lab Receives CTSC Pilot Grant to Advance AAC Research with UCP of Greater Cleveland
We are excited to announce that the Communication and Speech Emergence (CaSE) Lab has been awarded an Annual Pilot Grant through the Clinical and Translational Science Collaborative (CTSC). This highly competitive award supports inter-institutional, collaborative research with strong potential for clinical impact.
Our funded project, in partnership with United Cerebral Palsy (UCP) of Greater Cleveland and Dr. Samudragupta Bora at University Hospitals, will examine how caregiver participation in Club chAT—a summer community-based augmentative and alternative communication (AAC) program—shapes caregiver confidence, AAC integration at home, and family functioning. The project will use mixed methods to evaluate outcomes for caregivers of children and young adults who use AAC.
This work reflects our shared commitment to community-engaged research that improves communication outcomes and family well-being. We are especially grateful to our collaborators at UCP and to Dr. Bora for his expertise in neurodevelopmental follow-up and caregiver research.
Stay tuned for updates as we launch this exciting project!









This project is supported by the Clinical and Translational Science Collaborative of Northern Ohio which is funded by the National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences (NCATS) of the National Institutes of Health, UM1TR004528. The content is solely the responsibility of the authors and does not necessarily represent the official views of the NIH.

title: Summer Research Scholars Mentorship
text:
Dr. Long served as research mentor to five summer scholars in intensive research experience
This summer, Dr. Helen Long served as a research mentor to five Summer Scholars through the University Hospitals Health Services Research Center (HSRC) Summer Scholar Program. Her mentees represented a diverse range of training levels—from high school to medical school—and engaged in projects focused on improving healthcare delivery and communication outcomes for individuals with complex needs.
The six-week program offers intensive exposure to research methods, mentorship, and professional development, equipping students with the skills and inspiration to pursue careers in medicine and health services research. Under Dr. Long’s guidance, the scholars gained hands-on experience designing and interpreting research in their independent research projects surrounding the early identification and intervention of communication support needs for young children with or at risk for cerebral palsy. All students presented their final projects at the program’s closing symposium to their fellow scholars, mentors, and families.
“I was honored to mentor such a dedicated and inquisitive group of emerging scholars,” said Dr. Long. “Their enthusiasm and insight really highlight the importance of investing in the next generation of clinician-scientists.”
Now in its second year, the HSRC Summer Scholar Program is a cornerstone of University Hospitals’ commitment to education, equity, and translational research, helping to build a pipeline of future healthcare leaders.
You can learn more about this exciting program here.

title: A qualitative exploration of General Practice SLPs’ experiences in collaborative service delivery with AAC Specialists
text:
Home
    Publications
  



Long HL, Elmquist, M, & Seale, J. (under review). A qualitative exploration of General Practice SLPs’ experiences in collaborative service delivery with AAC Specialists. EdArXiv Preprints.



Abstract
Purpose: This qualitative study investigated how General Practice SLPs perceive their role and skill in the AAC evaluation process, as well as their objectives and experiences when collaborating with AAC Specialists.
Method: Nine General Practice SLPs from school-based and medical settings participated in semi-structed interviews describing their AAC experiences before and after engaging with the AAC Partnership Program, a collaborative service model among AAC Specialists and General Practice SLPs. Transcripts were analyzed using a thematic analysis approach.
Results: Participants reported seeking support from an AAC Specialist due to limited AAC experience, time constraints, and resource access. Collaborations were viewed as valuable for guiding efficient AAC evaluations, device selection, and skill development. However, participants varied in their interest in becoming independent AAC evaluators. While some sought to build AAC expertise, others preferred continued specialist involvement throughout the AAC process.
Conclusion: Partnerships among AAC Specialists and General Practice SLPs may offer valuable approaches to service delivery to promote equitable access to AAC services across settings. Flexible, scaffolded support offered through collaborative service delivery models allows for variability in team needs and preferences for the level of specialist involvement.

Biography
I am very interested in learning about speech development, especially during an individual’s early stages of life. I’ve gone through speech therapeutic programs growing up at a young age, and now I want to give back to the community by helping those who may have or are at risk of developing speech difficulties.
I am an undergraduate student majoring in Biology and Nutrition, and also on the pre-PA track. I am the Outreach Chair/External Affairs Executive for Empower Association at CWRU, and am now an undergraduate assistant in the Communication and Speech Emergence (CaSE) Laboratory.
I’m particularly interested in the OBGYN or pediatric side of the pre-health field and would love to work with children. I love playing badminton volleyball with my friends and enjoy rewatching high school slice-of-life anime outside of academics.

title: Master’s Students Meta-Analysis Presentations
text:
On October 15, 2025, faculty and students from the Communication Sciences (COSI) Program at CWRU gathered for the Meta-Analysis Poster Presentations event. This annual showcase highlights the work of second-year master’s students completing their non-thesis capstone projects, where they apply systematic and critical review methods to synthesize current evidence on clinically relevant topics in speech-language pathology through a meta-analysis.
Two members of the Communication and Speech Emergence (CaSE) Lab presented their independent meta-analyses at this event:

Kate Munz, Effects of non-invasive brain stimulation combined with speech-language therapy on naming ability in adults with post-stroke non-fluent aphasia.
Ava Ng, Effects of naming therapy on confrontational naming accuracy for individuals with primary progressive aphasia.

These projects are designed to demonstrate MA students’ rigorous engagement with research literature and their growing expertise in synthesizing evidence to inform clinical practice. Through this experience, COSI students gained experience critically examining methodologies, interpreting effect sizes, assessing quality, and identifying research gaps for future research as necessary skills for evidence-based clinical decision-making.
We’re proud of Kate and Ava and all of the 2nd year MA COSI students for their hard work and thoughtful presentations. Congratulations on a successful poster day!

title: CaSE Lab Holiday Party
text:
The CaSE Lab wrapped up the semester with a much-needed holiday study break and it was exactly the reset we all needed during finals week.
We kicked things off with a hot chocolate bar stocked with all the essentials (and plenty of marshmallows). Our spread of tamales, cookies, and snacks kept everyone happily fueled while working through end-of-semester studying. We took time to unwind with coloring sheets as a calming brain break to de-stress before finals.
We also gathering around for games and a chance to connect outside of research and deadlines. It was a fun and relaxing way to celebrate the semester’s accomplishments and to appreciate the community we’ve built in the lab.
Thank you to everyone who came, contributed food, or shared a little joy and humor during a busy week. We’re grateful for each member of the CaSE Lab and excited for everything ahead in the new year.
Happy holidays from all of us at the Communication and Speech Emergence Lab! 🎉☕🧡

title: ASHA 2025 Convention
text:
On November 20, 2025, Dr. Helen Long presented her latest research conducted in collaboration with Katherine Hustad (UW-Madison), Leslie Christensen (UW-Madison), Sydney Hayes Jensen (UW–Madison), Naomi Eichorn (University of Memphis), and D. Kimbrough Oller (University of Memphis) on early vocal and speech development in infants and young children with or at risk for cerebral palsy. This presentation was part of the ASHA Convention’s multi-part seminar series, “Vocal Communication and Early Detection of Various Emergent Conditions in Infants and Young Children”, which brought together investigators working to advance early detection science and improve developmental outcomes for infants with complex communication needs.
The seminar featured researchers from multiple universities sharing emerging evidence on how early vocal behaviors can support earlier identification of developmental conditions to an audience of both clinicians and scientists. Presentations were delivered by D. Kimbrough Oller (University of Memphis), Pumpki Su (UT Dallas), Hyunjoo Yoo (University of Alabama), Tanjala Gipson (UT Health Science Center), and Zahra Poursoroush (University of Memphis), offering an interdisciplinary perspective across autism, tuberous sclerosis complex, and cerebral palsy.
We’re proud to see CaSE Lab research represented on a national stage and grateful for the opportunity to contribute to this growing area of early detection and intervention for young children with or at risk for communication disabilities!

title: Timing of Intervals Between Utterances in Typically Developing Infants and Infants Later Diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder
text:
Home
    Publications
  


Poursoroush, Z., Ramsay, G., Yang, C.-C., Buder, E. H., Bene, E. R., Su, P. L., Yoo, H., Long, H. L., Klaiman, C., Pileggi, M. L., Brane, N., & Oller, D. K. (2025). Timing of Intervals Between Utterances in Typically Developing Infants and Infants Later Diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder. Brain Sciences, 15(8), 819. https://doi.org/10.3390/brainsci15080819


Abstract
Background: Understanding the origin and natural organization of early infant vocalizations is important for predicting communication and language abilities in later years. The very frequent production of speech-like vocalizations (hereafter “protophones”), occurring largely independently of interaction, is part of this developmental process. Objectives: This study aims to investigate the gap durations (time intervals) between protophones, comparing typically developing (TD) infants and infants later diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) in a naturalistic setting where endogenous protophones occur frequently. Additionally, we explore potential age-related variations and sex differences in gap durations. Methods: We analyzed ~1500 five min recording segments from longitudinal all-day home recordings of 147 infants (103 TD infants and 44 autistic infants) during their first year of life. The data included over 90,000 infant protophones. Human coding was employed to ensure maximally accurate timing data. This method included the human judgment of gap durations specified based on time-domain and spectrographic displays. Results and Conclusions: Short gap durations occurred between protophones produced by infants, with a mode between 301 and 400 ms, roughly the length of an infant syllable, across all diagnoses, sex, and age groups. However, we found significant differences in the gap duration distributions between ASD and TD groups when infant-directed speech (IDS) was relatively frequent, as well as across age groups and sexes. The Generalized Linear Modeling (GLM) results confirmed these findings and revealed longer gap durations associated with higher IDS, female sex, older age, and TD diagnosis. Age-related differences and sex differences were highly significant for both diagnosis groups.
